dt: {bc}one who gives heroic evidence of faith but does not suffer martyrdom
{bc}a priest who is one's regular spiritual guide

et: Middle English {it}confessour,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}confessur,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}confessor,{/it} going back to Late Latin, "one professing a religious faith, one confessing sins," from {it}confitērī{/it} "to profess faith" (going back to Latin, "to admit [a fact, the truth of a statement or charge], reveal") + Latin {it}-tor,{/it} agent suffix {ma}{mat|confess|}{/ma}
The word {it}confessor{/it} occurs in some Old English texts, though usually with Latin or ambiguous inflection.
shortdef: one who gives heroic evidence of faith but does not suffer martyrdom
